title: The Thinker
stories: The Detroit Institute of Arts has a collection of over 60,000 works of art across a wide range of media. One of the most visible is their cast of sculptor August Rodin’s iconic sculpture, The Thinker. More than twenty monumental size bronze casts of the sculpture are in museums around the world. Rodin made the first small plaster version around 1880, but the first large-scale bronze cast was not completed until 1902.

title: Spirit of Detroit
stories: In 2013, art dealer and art historian Eric Ian Hornak Spoutz was quoted in the Detroit News stating that the value of the statue is in excess of $1,000,000.

title: School of Iron
stories: The sculpture garden at MBAD African Bead Museum houses 18 outdoor installations as well as the African Bead Gallery, N'kisi House and the African Language Wall.

title: Monument to Joe Louis "The Fist"
stories: The sculpture was vandalized by two Caucasian-American males in 2004, who covered it in white paint and left a sign which read, "Courtesy of Fighting Whities".

title: Antoine de la Mothe Cadillac Statue
stories: The founder of Detroit, Antoine Laumet in Saint Nicolas de la Grave, was from the Tarn et Garonne department in the Midi Pyrenées region of France.

title: Dodge Memorial Fountain
stories: Vandals did more than $1 million in damage to Hart Plaza in January '16, leaving the Horace E. Dodge and Son Memorial Fountain inoperable and fixing the fountain will cost $300,000 to $400,000.

title: Free Form One
stories: City Sculpture is a 501c3 non­profit entity.

title: Free Form Two
stories: It is designed to provide an educational experience for mainly high school and college students.

title: Free FormThree
stories: The park is dedicated to exposing the public to experimental sculpture work in Detroit.

title: Free Form Four
stories: Artist statement: "I have lived and worked my entire life as a sculptor in the city of my birth — Detroit, Michigan. The art studio and house that I built has served as my welding shop, and printmaking and painting studio since the 1980s."

title: Free Form Five
stories: Artist statement: "I feel proud to be a part of this community where I live and work, and I am likewise honored to be a part of a city whose challenges have helped create more provoking art, and a tighter and more coherent art community."

title: Free Form Six
stories: Artist statement: "Having made many indoor and outdoor welded sculptures throughout my career — on permanent display in the City of Detroit and surrounding suburbs, as well as several works on display in New York City and elsewhere in North America — it is now my goal to create a permanent exhibit space for my large-scale work."

title: Free Form Seven
stories: Artist statement: "I have nearly sixty pieces of sculpture made since 1980, including several new pieces currently in the works —  welded steel, bronze and stainless steel that I plan to feature in a neighborhood outdoor sculpture park in my mid-town Detroit neighborhood, for the benefit of people who live there, the Wayne State students and faculty who traverse the area, and for the nearby public Detroit Public Jefferson middle school."

title: Free Form Eight
stories: Artist statement: "My vision is for at least a 200ft by 200ft space for the park, with a dozensculptures to be initially installed, and more over time. Ultimately I see the park becoming a site for classes and workshops in sculptural art with visiting artists invited to display and give lectures and demonstrations in the park."

title: Free Form Nine
stories: Artist statement: “The art scene in Detroit has just exploded.”

title: Free Form Twenty Nine
stories: His 27 “crops” aren’t stalks of corn but twisting towers of recycled steel, some as high as 12 feet, that populate this once vacant strip of Midtown.

title: Ride it Sculpture Park
stories: A public park along the Davison Expressway, combining elements of skateboarding with public art and greenspace into a unique neighborhood landmark.

title: Gordie Howe Statue
stories: Home of the 11-time Stanley Cup Champion Detroit Red Wings, Joe Louis Arena proudly stands along the banks of the Detroit River.

title: Ty Cobb
stories: With Cobb leading the Tigers to three league championships, attendance flourished and baseball became important in the city in the 1920s.

title: Charlie Gehringer
stories: Gehringer had a great career, hitting above .300 thirteen seasons and finishing with a career batting average of .320 in the 1920s

title: Hank Greenberg
stories: Hank Greenberg statue at Comerica Park stands approx. 13 ft tall and is cast in stainless steel. It sits on a granite base and stands with 5 other Detroit Tiger Hall of Fame statues.

title: Willie Horton
stories: Willie Horton, who played with the Detroit Tigers, with a statue made in his image, during a ceremony where his No. 23 was retired on July 15, 2000, in Detroit.

title: Al Kaline
stories: Al Kaline joined the Tigers when they were in Philadelphia on June 25, 1953 and played in the game that day as an 18 year old.

title: Hal Newhouser
stories: Newhouser was known for his fiery temper. Apparently, he was estranged from the Detroit Tigers from his release in 1953 until 1997 when the team ceremoniously retired his number.

title: Atom Gazelle
stories: Richard Bennett is a self-taught, Detroit-born sculptor.  When this piece of art was installed, it was meant to be the first of a herd of five gazelles.

title: Ludington Plaza Statues
stories: The nine bronzed sculptures throughout the five-acre park each tells a story that relates to Ludington's rich history.

title: James J. Brady Memorial
stories: This statue commemorates the significant work of a James J. Brady, who sought to improve the welfare of Detroit’s young children early in the last century.

title: Normanno Wedge I
location: College for Creative Studies Ford Campus
stories: This 1983 sculpture by Beverly Pepper is one of several modern works installed at this outdoor sculpture garden on the campus of the College for Creative Studies.

title: Statue of Robert Burns
stories: The statue of Robert Burns was built with donations from English immigrants.

title: Michigan Soldiers and Sailors Monument
stories: This sculpture stands in a prominent location on the southeast tip of Campus Martius Park, where five principal thoroughfares—Michigan Avenue, Monroe Street, Cadillac Square, Fort Street, and Woodward Avenue—convene on the traffic circle.

title: Shinola Detroit Clocks
stories: Inspired by the city clocks that were popular fixtures on sidewalks of American cities in the late 1800s, Shinola installed them at Cobo Center, Eastern Market, at the intersection of Cass and Canfield, and at the corner of Milwaukee and Cass in front of the College for Creative Studies A. Alfred Taubman Center for Design Education.

title: Mayor Hazen Pingree Monument
location:
Woodward Avenue and
West Adams Street
stories: The Hazen S. Pingree Monument honors a man who served as Detroit mayor from 1890 to 1897, leaving office only after being elected governor of Michigan. Old Ping, as he was known, was named one of the 10 best mayors in U.S. history.

title: Boogaloo
stories: Artist statement: "I strive to be a part of the solution. I see and understand how order is needed in the world and in our individual lives. My experiences have granted me knowledge of how to create art and how to see beauty in everything that exists."

title: Side Talking Kay
stories: Artist statement, "Even in the smallest molecule or things in this life that we can’t see, we are all bound by this same energy, we are all bound by gravity and we breathe the same air. I can see the evolution of life in everything, in every minute second. How beautiful it is to witness this process in action.

title: Midmiem
stories: Beginning in 1968, Soffer’s sculpture has been seen at Lincoln Center, Battery Park, the Indianapolis Museum of Art, Queens College, Bard College, New York University, Harvard University, Hampshire College, and the Sculpture Park in East Hampton, New York.

title:
Statues of General Anthony Wayne, Antoine De La Mothe Cadillac,
Chief Pontiac and Robert Navarre
stories: On the Michigan Avenue façade above the major entrance of the Book Cadillac Hotel at the intersection of Michigan Avenue and Washington Boulevard in downtown Detroit.

title: Mural on the west side of the Cass Motors Building
stories: The Carhartt business was founded in Detroit in 1889 to manufacture extremely durable apparel for railroad workers.

title: Gateway To Freedom
stories: The sculpture shows six fugitive slaves ready to board a boat to cross to Canada. The gentleman pointing from Detroit to Windsor is George DeBaptist, a Detroit resident who helped slaves get across the river to freedom.

title: Sunbeam Sculpture
stories: The work portrays the interaction of water and sun in an urban environment.

title: Spirit Renewal
stories: Charles McGee was the first winner of the Kresge Eminent Artist Award in 2008.  The program is now administered by the College for Creative Studies and honors Detroit-area artists.

title: Spanish-American War Commerative
stories: Allen Newman, who lived from 1875 to 1940, was a reasonably well-known and popular sculptor of the early Twentieth Century.  He specialized in outdoor sculptures commemorating the Spanish-American War.

title: Joe Louis Sculpture
stories: Boxing was an extremely popular sport in the Depression decade, and Joe Louis was an exceptionally talented fighter.

title: General Alexander Macomb Monument
stories: Instead of a comfortable life in Detroit, Alexander Macomb joined the U.S. Army in 1799 and would make a name for himself during the War of 1812 as a brigadier general at the Battle of Plattsburgh in New York in September 1814.

title: Little Water Girl
stories: Around 1917, the WCTU commissioned the sculpting of a statue of a young girl catching rain in a small bucket. This was done to honor Lilian Ames Stevens who was the second president of the WCTU and a leading suffergette.

title: Demetrius Ypsilanti Bust
stories: Demetrius Ypsilanti was a field general in the Greek army during the country's struggle for independence from the Ottoman empire. He successfully defended the Citadel of Argos in 1824.

title: William Livingstone Memorial Lighthouse
stories: "The lighthouse has always seemed to me to be symbolic of two primary ideals, reliability and service, and that this permanent memorial has appropriately taken this shape well signifies the extent to which the life of Mr. Livingstone fulfilled these ideals." - H.S. King, Deputy Commissioner of Lighthouses

title: Wings of Learning
stories: G. Alden Smith (1912-1984) was a sculptor and art director from Highland Park, Michigan.

title: Upfront
location: College for Creative Studies Ford Campus
stories: Anthony Caro's questioning approach opened up new possibilities, both formally and with regard to subject matter. His innovative work as well as his teaching led to a flowering and a new confidence in sculpture worldwide.

title: The Hand of God
stories: In 1930, Murphy ran as a Democrat and was elected Mayor of Detroit. He served from 1930 to 1933, during the first years of the Great Depression. He presided over an epidemic of urban unemployment, a crisis in which 100,000 were unemployed in the summer of 1931.

title: Father Gomidas Vartabed Statue
stories: Detroit's large and prosperous Armenian community erected this statue in 1981 to commemorate their dead co-ethnics and remind us of the tragedy of ethnic slaughters.

title: Tribute to General Anthony Wayne
stories: General Wayne was the first successful US commander to win a reputation for soundly defeating Indians. He also helped to develop an effective strategy for controlling and removing Indians, a strategy that was followed in Michigan, Wisconsin and the upper Midwest.

title: Sculpture Honoring Professor Andrzej W. Olbrot
stories: A Wayne State graduate student in the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Wlodzimierz Dedecjus, walked into that classroom, pulled out a rifle and shot Professor Olbrot to death.

title: United Foundation Torch
stories: This sculpture continues to bring attention to the United Way campaign

title: Johann Friedrich von Schiller Sculpture
stories: This statue of the German poet and playwright was commissioned by Detroit's German-American community in 1908 at a cost of $12,000.

title: Victory Eagle
stories: Although abstracted, the Victory Eagle appears to be landing on the surface of the pedestal. Moreover, it is situated above the eye-level of the viewer and looks down with glaring eyes. Its upraised wings, sharp beak, and talons add to its fierceness.

title: Father Clement Kern Statue
stories: Father Clement Kern spent virtually his entire career at the Holy Trinity Church, specializing in self-help programs such as a credit union and counseling for alcoholics.

title: Jeune Fille et sa Suite
stories: Many artists made contour line drawings on paper, but Calder was the first to use wire to create three-dimensional line "drawings" of people, animals, and objects. These "linear sculptures" introduced line into sculpture as an element unto itself.

title: Horse Sculpture
location: College for Creative Studies Ford Campus
stories: Duchamp-Villon transformed the natural forms of a horse into the elements of a machine, a not uncommon theme in the work of avant-garde artists of the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries.

title: Hip and Spine (Stone Chair Setting)
location: College for Creative Studies Ford Campus
stories: Many of Richard Nonas works – made of such materials as timbers, linear beams, granite curbstones, and steel planes – rest directly on the ground and function less as formal aesthetic objects, and more as spatial markers.

title: Helios Trail
stories: The sculpture was intended to represent the bright future of the College of Engineering at Wayne State.

title: Statue of Major General Alpheus Starkey Williams
stories: Williams, a Detroiter, was a congressman, a judge, a lawyer, a postmaster, a newspaper publisher and a failed gubernatorial candidate, but he made a name for himself in the military, serving in the Mexican-American War and for the Union in the Civil War.

title: Obelisk
stories: The Obelisk commemorates Judge Augustus Woodward’s plan for the redesigned city of Detroit after the disastrous fire of 1805.

title: Statue of Abraham Lincoln
stories: When the Ford Motor Company ceased building Lincolns in that massive factory, Leland’s heirs gave the statue of President Lincoln to the city of Detroit.

title: Le Fleuve et La Garonne
stories: French sculptor known for his decorative work at the palace of Versailles and for his portrait busts, which introduced a trend toward the sharpened depiction of individual character.

title: Leaping Gazelle
stories: Since the gazelle is not native to Michigan, Fredericks made four animals that are, and placed them around the gazelle on Belle Isle. These animals are the otter, grouse, hawk and rabbit.

title: Statue of General Thaddeus Kosciuszko
stories: When the Tsar granted amnesty, Kosciuszko immediately came to the United States where he sought both medical treatment and back pay from the military. Congress appropriated $15,000 and granted him 500 acres along the Scioto River where Columbus is now located.

title: Bust of Mikolaj Kopernik
stories: To commemorate the 500th anniversary of the famous Polish astronomer, Mikolaj Kopernik, the Copernicus Observance Committee presented this statue to the city of Detroit.

title: William Cotter Maybury Monument
stories: Maybury “won local, if not national, renown as a baby-kisser. He just cooed his way into office telling mothers how beautiful their babies were,” the Detroit Free Press wrote in 1941.

title: Ludington Plaza Statues
stories: Detroit’s first city hall was a small Greek revival structure designed by architect Alpheus White and completed in 1835.

title: Russell Alexander Alger Memorial Fountain
stories: The monument features a bronze statue of a woman about 7 feet tall wearing a headdress and a flowing gown and carrying a sword and a shield that bears the state seal. Her right hand is raised in greeting. She is the bronze personification of the state of Michigan.

title: Stevens Thompson Mason Statue
stories: This monument honors the man who led Michigan to statehood.

title: Merrill Fountain
stories: Palmer represented Detroit in the Michigan Senate in 1879 and 1880, and then was selected to represent Michigan in the U.S. Senate from 1883 to 1889.

title: Bagley Memorial Fountain
stories: Richardson modeled the monument after a ciborium in St. Mark’s Basilica in Venice. The fountain stands more than 18 feet tall with ornate Romanesque details at the top and Byzantine columns.

title: Levi L. Barbour Memorial Fountain
stories: His sculptures can be found in more than 150 public and corporate locations.

title: Monroe Monument Marker/Woodward Monument Marker
stories: To celebrate the tricentennial of the founding of Detroit, a major renovation of Campus Martius was undertaken with the installation of new works of art.

title: Nordkyn
stories: Innovation and clarity of vision have marked Robert Murray’s practice since the early 1960s, making him one of Canada’s foremost sculptors.

title: Normanno Wedge I
location: College for Creative Studies Ford Campus
stories: All of Pepper's sculptures from the beginning of her sculptural career were displayed outdoors.

title: Charles Brook’s Memorial Peace Fountain
stories: This fountain is assembled and put in place in May of every year and then removed with the onset of cold weather.

title: Nancy Brown Peace Carillon
stories: In 1970, the bells of the majestic tower went quiet. Vandals — who knocked out stained-glass windows at the top of the tower — and pigeons destroyed the mechanism that played the songs.

title: Commodore Oliver Hazard Perry’s Canons
stories: Battle of Lake Erie hero Oliver Hazard Perry is characterized as being an all around patriot who saved the American cause during the War of 1812.

title: Pewabic Pottery Company
stories: The building and its contents are designated a National Historic Landmark. Today, Pewabic is Michigan’s only historic pottery.

title: Phylon
stories: Pylon is a word of Greek origin referring to an Egyptian gateway structure that resembled a truncated pyramid.

title: Statue of Pope John Paul II
stories: This commemorates the Pope's visit to Hamtramck in September 22, 1969. Dedicated by Archbishop Edmund Szoka of Detroit.

title: Brigadier General Casmir Pulaski Statue
stories: Pulaski was, seemingly, a very aggressive military leader who wanted to lead forces against the British.

title: Father Solanus Casey Statue
stories: Solanus Casey was an American Capuchin friar and priest who was known during his lifetime as a wonderworker and is the first United States-born man to be declared "venerable" by the Roman Catholic Church.

title: Bust of Lewis Cass
stories: He was appointed governor of the Territory of Michigan in 1813 and served until 1831. His tenure was marked by good relations with the numerous Indian tribes under his jurisdiction.

title: Starting Point of the July, 1967 Racial Riot
location: 9125 Twelfth Street at the corner of Twelfth and Clairmont
stories: Early on Sunday morning July 23, 1967; Detroit police raided a "blind pig" at this location expecting to find a few people violating the law by drinking in an unlicensed establishment.

title: Horace H. Rackham Memorial Fountain
stories: The historic and famed Horace H. Rackham Memorial Fountain, located in the center of the Zoo, was built in 1939 and dedicated to the first president of the Zoological Commission.

title: Father Gabriel Richard Statue
stories: Father Gabriel Richard, a French priest assigned in 1798 to French-speaking Detroit, embraced the ideals of the Enlightenment and the French Revolution, and was a force behind the founding of the University of Michigan in 1817.

title: The River of Knowledge Mosaic
stories: French architectural styles were increasing popular in the United States at this time so Anderson apparently toned down the Italianate styling in the ten- or eleven-year interval between designing the edifice and its completion.

title: Bust of Christopher Columbus
stories: Early in the 1960s, an attractive Cass Avenue entrance was added to the marvelous Detroit Public Library building that Cass Gilbert designed in the early 1920s. At this time two wings were added to the building. This Cass Avenue entrance features white marble facades, red columns and dark green marble.

title: Bust of Christoforo Columbo
stories: On October 12, 2015, a vandal put a hachet on the forhead of the sculpture of Christopher Columbus.

title: Johann Friedrich von Schiller Sculpture
stories: Schiller is one of the key figures in the history of German philosophic thought.  He is widely recognized as one of the most accomplished poets and dramatists to write in German.

title: Continuity Tower
location: West Grand Boulevard and Third Street
stories: Robert Sestok welded together various pieces of steel that he found in Detroit to create an airy tower that gets more complicated as its height increases.

title: The James Scott Fountain
stories: The back of the chair holding Scott’s statue says: “For the enjoyment of the people and for the adornment of his native city. James Scott bequeathed to Detroit his fortune to be used in the construction of this fountain. Erected MCMXXIII. From the good deed of one comes benefit to many.”

title: George Armstrong Custer Equestrian Monument
stories: The statue shows Custer wearing his Civil War uniform; in keeping with sculptural convention, his horse has , all four feet on the ground, as Custer did not die during that period of service.

title: Sentinel X
stories: Morris Brose is a sculptor from Detroit, Michigan born in Poland.

title: Dancing Maidens
stories: Stonorov died when Reuther's Gates Learjet 23 crashed on approach to Emmet County Airport in Pellston, Michigan. Also killed were Reuther's wife, his bodyguard, and the plane's pilot and copilot.

title: Partners
stories: This sculpture depicts a figure of a young newsboy dropping coins from one hand into another. Under his left arm he holds a bundle of papers, and over his left shoulder he carries a blacking kit. His dog sits at his feet.

title: The Reverend Samuel Francis Smith Memorial Flagpole
stories: This flagpole on Belle Isle pays tribute to the Rev. Samuel Francis Smith, who wrote the song “America (My Country, ‘Tis of Thee).”

title: Passo di Danza
stories: In 1939 Manzu started a series of bronze bas-reliefs about the death of Jesus Christ; the works, exhibited in Rome in 1942, were criticized by the Fascist government and the ecclesiastical authorities.

title: Edison Memorial Fountain
stories: The plaque on the fountain reads: "Erected by the people of the citty of Detroit in commemoration of the achievements of Thomas Alva Edison the realm of electricity October twenty-first in the year one thousand nine hundred twenty-nine."

title: The Entrance
stories: Piet received the key to the city during the dedication of his sculpture. The 22-foot sculpture was commissioned by the city to commemorate the International Theatre Olympiad, held in Detroit in 1975.

title: Henry Ford Statue
stories: The original plan was to have a statue of Henry Ford and a little boy, symbolizing encouragement in business and industry to future generations.

title: Mozarabe
location: College for Creative Studies Ford Campus
stories: While at Yale, Serra worked with Josef Albers on his book The Interaction of Color (1963).

title: Grand Couple
location: College for Creative Studies Ford Campus
stories: During World War II Étienne Martin was a prisoner in Germany and was liberated in 1941.

title: Goddess of the Golden Thighs
location: College for Creative Studies Ford Campus
stories: This unnamed, archetypal goddess, with her massive, splayed thighs supported on a primitive altar of rough-hewn pillars, is a potent symbol of fertility. According to the artist, she represents “the birth of the universe.”

title: Transcending Arch
stories: The arch was commissioned as a Michigan Labor Legacy Landmark to recognize the contributions of the city's laborers and skilled tradespeople.

title: Trilogy Sculpture
stories: Nevelson carefully arranged the objects in order to historicize the debris within the new, narrative context of her wall sculptures. The stories embodied within her works resulted from her cumulative experiences - as a Jewish child relocated to America from Russia, as an artist training in New York City and Germany, and as a hard-working, successful woman.

title: Harriet Tubman Statue
stories: The bronze sculpture depicts Miss Tubman grasping the hand of a young boy and leading him on a walk.  DeDecker captures both compassion and a steely determination in the features of Miss Tubman’s face.

title: Gracehoper
stories: Artist statement: "I think of the Gracehoper as intimate rather than monumental. People have some sensuous connection with this work. They can move around it, walk under it, go through it."

title: Grand Army of the Republic Memorial
stories: The Grand Army of the Republic (GAR) was founded in Decatur, Illinois in 1866 and, quite rapidly, became the largest and most powerful of the Union Army veterans group.

title: Statue of Ernie Harwell
stories: Someone ripped the original eyeglasses off the statue in 2011.

title: Bust of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr
stories: Although Martin Luther King Jr. today is often remembered as being an amazing public speaker, he got a C in public speaking during his first year at seminary.

title: Nydia, the Blind Girl of Pompeii
stories: This statue is based on a character from Edward Bulwer-Lytton’s popular 1834 novel "The Last Days of Pompeii." In the episode depicted here, Nydia and her two companions attempt to flee the city after the eruption of Mount Vesuvius.

title: Detroit Deliquescence
location: College for Creative Studies Taubman Campus
stories: The 17-foot sculpture was executed out of salvaged auto parts.

title: Heidelberg Project
stories: Tyree Guyton has waged a personal war on urban blight on Detroit's East Side, transforming his neighborhood into a living indoor/outdoor art gallery.

title: The X and Its Tail
location: College for Creative Studies Ford Campus
stories: Calder’s kinetic sculptures are regarded as being amongst the earliest manifestations of an art that consciously departed from the traditional notion of the art work as a static object and integrated the ideas of gesture and immateriality as aesthetic factors.

title: Ashtabula
location: College for Creative Studies Ford Campus
stories: Hall is the last artist to be awarded the top honor at the DIA's final version of the annual Exhibition of Michigan Artists in the 1980's.

title: United We Stand
stories: The abstract figures with arms outstretched signify people coming together to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the Detroit Riots.

title: Baphomet
location: Detroit Chapter of the Satanic Temple
stories: Baphomet, the goat-headed wraith who, after centuries of various appropriations, is now the totem of contemporary Satanism. The horned idol sits on a throne adorned with a pentagram and his legs end in hooves. It might seem more menacing if not for the two bronze-statue children standing on either side of him — a girl on his left; a boy on his right; both are looking up at him earnestly.
This sculpture depicts a second baseman throwing a runner out at first base and is located in the sculpture park outside the Detroit Athletic Club.

title: The Finish
stories: “Schomberg has a great style representing the intensity of sports and athletics…The sculptures will be a very visible and dramatic statement about renewal in Detroit and a landmark moment in the Detroit Athletic Club’s history in the community.”-Ted Gillary, the club’s executive manager

title: Tigers
stories: The tiger at the North Gate is 15 feet tall. Several more grace the façade plus two atop the left field scoreboard have eyes that light up after each home run.

title: Whatsoever You Do
stories: According to Schmalz, the sculpture is a visual representation of the Gospel of Matthew 25:40, which depicts Jesus in the form of a homeless man.

title: Jesus The Homeless
location: Ss. Peter and Paul Jesuit Catholic Church
stories: This is a statue of a man (Jesus Christ) with crucifixion marks on his feet sleeping on a park bench.

title: The Procession (A Family)
location: Blue Cross Blue Shield of Detroit
stories: Thirteen nude figures grouped together in various poses in a fountain. Three figures carry a woman balances a small child on her proper right hip. One woman lies on her proper left side with her abdomen cut; while another figure dives or tumbles with his feet protruding from a wall. Another woman stands holding a baby.

title: Book Sculpture
stories: Gilsdorf's idea for the sculpture was for kids to be able to interact with the piece.

title: The Man in the City
stories: Artist statement: "It can be a frightening image a times, it can be someone you are, or someone you might be. I don’t want to plant too many seeds, because everyone has their own identification with it. I like people to embrace it for what it is and make it their own."

title: Charles Lang Freer House Historical Marker
stories: Charles Lang Freer House Historical Marker is also close to The Merrill-Palmer Institute Historical Marker and Omega Psi Phi Historical Marker.
